titleStmt.title: ཆ་ཤས་ཀྱི་ཡན་ལག་ཅེས་བྱ་བའི་རབ་ཏུ་བྱེད་པ།
cha shas kyi yan lag ces bya ba'i rab tu byed pa/
Hastavāla­nāma­prakaraṇa
An Exposition called “Grasping with the Hand”

bibl.author: Āryadeva
bod kyi lo tsa ba rin chen bzang po
Śraddhākaravarman

notesStmt.note: A translation of this text (and its commentary) is found in the Chinese Buddhist canon (Taishō 1620 and 1621, attributed to Dignāga) wherein the text’s title is rendered as 解捲論 (“Treatise of a Clenched Fist”). Thomas and Ui [1918] take the Tibetan title (lit. “Branches of the Parts”) to be a “free translation” of the Sanskrit and translate the Sanskrit title by taking vāla (√val) as “to roll” or “to twist” and hence hasta-vāla as “clenched fist” or “grasping with the hand,” noting that the text contains five verses symbolic of five fingers and a sixth summation verse symbolic of the act of closing them in grasping something. I have followed their line of reasoning in translating the title as well.
